Dialogue.NPCText:
Before you stands a striking knight clad in gilded azure plate, his Drace’s Azure Crest helm sweeping back like stylized wings. A cloak of shifting blue and silver ripples behind him, marking him as Aerilon’s Skyguard.

He meets your gaze, equal parts chivalry and pride.

“Stand tall, traveler. You address Ser Velyan Drace, Gilded Knight of the Skyguard—sworn shield of Aerilon, commander of our flying legion, and, though my blood hails from Wind, my loyalty is cast here among the clouds.

To what purpose do you ascend to the Spires this day? Adventure? Duty? Or the hope of Aerilon’s favor?”

Option.text: I seek purpose worthy of the Skyguard.
Tell me your story, Ser Velyan.
Who leads Aerilon’s defenders?
What dangers do you face here?
I would hear more of your past, Ser Drace.
I was only admiring your armor.
I’m just passing by.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Velyan smiles faintly, gaze distant.

“I was born second son to House Drace of Wind—a family of mages who believed steel was beneath them. Yet I found beauty not in spellbooks, but in the flight of the griffon, the ring of steel, and the honor of the oath.

I came to Aerilon to forge the Skyguard: knights who soar as high as the mages dream. Here, I serve Lady Selara Vael—though she clings to isolation, and I would see Aerilon rise as a beacon against Minax.
My brother remains in Wind. He thinks me a traitor. Yet I am bound to this city—heart, soul, and sky.”

Option.text: Why serve Aerilon over your family?
What of Selara Vael?
What is the Skyguard’s purpose?
Let us speak of more urgent matters.

Dialogue.NPCText: “Duty is the truest lineage. Wind’s nobles hoard secrets in their mountain halls, content to watch the world burn below. Aerilon—at least in my vision—soars above petty divides. Here, I forged brotherhood in battle, and I would rather die as Skyguard than rule as a Wind-born shade.”

Option.text: You speak with conviction. How may I help?
What of your brother?

Dialogue.NPCText: “My elder brother, Lord Malchior Drace, is a councilor in Wind—ambitious, clever, but bitter as winter. We have not spoken in years, and I fear Wind’s isolation may soon give way to darkness, or to Minax’s corruption. Still, blood binds, even across the sky.”

Option.text: Let us discuss Aerilon’s needs.
Is Malchior an enemy to Aerilon?

Dialogue.NPCText:
Velyan’s jaw tightens.
“He would say no. Yet he schemes, as all Wind’s nobles do. If you ever find yourself in Wind, walk carefully. And if you meet a Drace, mention my name only if you wish to test their patience.”

Option.text: Thank you for the warning. Back to business…

Dialogue.NPCText: “Lady Selara Vael is Aerilon’s mind and shield, and I am her sword. She is visionary, but clings to solitude. I press her for alliances—Trinsic, even Britain itself—but she sees only the threats below. Still, without her, this city would be little more than another Wind, adrift and dreaming.”

Option.text: Let us turn to your purpose, commander.

Dialogue.NPCText:
“The Skyguard are knights and riders who defend Aerilon not from towers, but from the backs of Reptalons, gryphons, and even summoned wind serpents. Our order is young—fewer than fifty sworn, but each knows the sky as others know the ground.
Our greatest need is steeds and those who understand them. The threat from Minax grows, and her beasts blacken the clouds. To stand a chance, we must bond new Reptalons—creatures only true scholars can tame.”

Option.text: What does this mean for me?
Tell me more about these flying mounts.

Dialogue.NPCText:
“Reptalons are rare—half-dragon, half-bird, born of cloud and spellcraft. Most are wild, but a handful of scholars on the surface can communicate with them. Only with their aid can we breed and train a new flight.
I have fashioned a Skyward Phylactery—an arcane vessel needed by these scholars. But I cannot leave Aerilon, nor trust the city’s spies. I would see it delivered by a blade untainted by courtly schemes.”

Option.text: I’ll deliver your Skyward Phylactery.
What is a Skyward Phylactery?
Who are these scholars?
I’m not interested in such work.

Dialogue.NPCText: “A Skyward Phylactery is a crystal reliquary, infused with the essence of cloud and wing. It allows a Reptalon Scholar to establish a bond with a new hatchling—ensuring loyalty and harnessing their innate magic. Without it, our mounts would run wild, or worse, fall prey to Minax’s taming spells.”

Option.text: I see. I’ll accept the delivery.
This sounds too perilous for me.

Dialogue.NPCText: “Most are reclusive, found in remote eyries—never cities. Seek one known as a ‘Reptalon Scholar’; only they have earned a Reptalon’s trust. You’ll find them outside Aerilon’s reach, often hidden in the wilds or deep in druidic circles. They will recognize the seal of my house and the azure hue of the phylactery.”

Option.text: Very well. I’ll deliver the Skyward Phylactery.
I don’t wish to get involved with Reptalons.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Ser Velyan leans close, lowering his voice.
“Aerilon needs more than mages—we need riders, and those who walk between worlds. I have crafted the Skyward Phylactery, a relic required by the Reptalon Scholars outside our city. Deliver this to one such scholar—none but a true Reptalon Scholar may accept it.

If you succeed, you’ll win not only Aerilon’s favor, but the respect of the Skyguard. But beware—Minax covets any artifact that might sway the skies to her cause, and even Wind’s spies might try to claim it. Will you fly this errand for Aerilon?”

Option.text: I will deliver the Phylactery.
Tell me more about the risks.
Why not send a Skyguard knight?
This is not my path.

Dialogue.NPCText:
“Danger soars with every wind. Minax’s harpies stalk the routes below; Wind’s agents seek any leverage against Aerilon. If you’re pursued, trust in your wits, not your blade—there are runes within the phylactery’s case to shield it once, but only once.
Succeed, and you may one day ride beside us. Fail, and even the clouds may mourn.”

Option.text: I accept. Give me the Phylactery.
On second thought, I must decline.

Dialogue.NPCText: “If I could, I would. But Skyguard knights are known to every hawk and whisperer in the sky. You, outsider, are an unknown. That is your greatest strength—use it well.”

Option.text: You have my word. I will deliver it.
This task is not for me.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Ser Velyan produces a gleaming azure reliquary, etched with the twin crests of Aerilon and House Drace.
“Take this Skyward Phylactery. Seek a Reptalon Scholar beyond Aerilon’s bounds. Deliver it only to one worthy of the name—and none other. Return with news of your success, and the Skyguard will remember your courage.”

Option.text: I will not fail you, Ser Drace.

Dialogue.NPCText: “The skies are no longer safe. Minax’s wyverns grow bold, and Wind’s conjurers probe our borders. We Skyguard ride every dusk and dawn, but the horizon darkens. Aerilon’s peace is fragile as glass—help us keep it unbroken.”

Option.text: If I can aid you, say the word.
I should take my leave.

Dialogue.NPCText:
He laughs—deep, genuine.
“This armor? Every piece is a tale. The Drace’s Azure Crest helm is a family relic, once worn by a Wind warlord who slew a dragon above the clouds. The Skyward Bastion plate was forged by Salia Moontide herself—she claims the metal sings in a storm.
These Stormforged Vambraces were a gift from the first Reptalon I rode. Each part is both shield and memory. Should you ever earn Skyguard steel, wear it with pride.”

Option.text: Perhaps one day I will.
Farewell, Ser Drace.

Dialogue.NPCText: “Then may the skies bear you lightly, traveler. Should you seek cause, the Skyguard’s banner flies high above the Azure Market.”

Option.text: On second thought, I wish to serve Aerilon.
I’ll be going now.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Ser Velyan nods solemnly.

“You honor me with your curiosity. Not many care to ask about a knight’s *before*. They see the armor, not the forging.”

“Very well. Ask what you will—memories weigh less when shared.”

Option.text: What was your childhood in Wind like?
Tell me of your first Reptalon.
Have you ever loved another?
How do you spend your time off the battlefield?
I’d rather return to more pressing matters.

Dialogue.NPCText:
“My father was a noble, cold and brilliant. My brother followed his path: tomes, debates, arrogance. I did not. I once skipped an exam to watch the city hawks train above the cliffs. When I was caught, my punishment was to scribe five hundred lines on ‘discipline’. I copied them with a broken quill—deliberately.

That was the day I learned defiance is a blade all its own.”

Option.text: A fitting lesson for a Skyguard.
You have always walked a different path.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Velyan’s eyes soften.

“Her name was Aelthir. Wild, proud, and clever. She burned three saddles before she let me ride her. I trained in secret—Reptalon bonding was banned for my caste. When we finally soared together, I wept. Wind’s towers fell away, and the horizon stretched like a promise.”

“She died defending Aerilon during its third storm siege. I wear her scale over my heart.”

You notice a faint shimmer beneath his breastplate. A soft blue scale, faintly glowing.

Option.text: A worthy bond. I hope to ride one someday.
She would be proud of what you’ve built.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Velyan chuckles softly, voice lowering.

“A bold question. I’ve known comradeship, yes. Shared campfires, battlefields, and fleeting moments stolen beneath moonlight. But duty… duty always reclaims me.”

He looks at you, lingering for a moment.
“Perhaps in another life—or if this war ever ends.”

Option.text: Perhaps that life isn’t so far away.
A soldier’s heart beats loud, but not always free.

Dialogue.NPCText:
“Hobbies? Hah. I read old ballads—especially the tragic ones. I also carve small wooden Reptalon tokens; calming, in a way. Sometimes I teach cadets to recite Skyguard Oaths blindfolded. Builds memory and humility.”

He grins, eyes twinkling.
“If you ever want a hand-carved Reptalon, bring me a sky maple branch and time.”

Option.text: I’ll keep my eyes open for sky maple.
Option.action: SendMessage:Ser Velyan may now accept sky maple branches.

Option.text: That’s… oddly charming for a battle commander.
